Developing sulfur cathodes with high catalytic activity on accelerating the sluggish redox kinetics of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) and unveiling their mechanisms are pivotal for advanced lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries. Herein, MoS2 is verified to reduce the Gibbs free energy for rate-limiting step of sulfur reduction and the dissociation energy of lithium sulfide (Li2S) for the first time employing theoretical calculations. The MoS2 nanosheets coated on mesoporous hollow carbon spheres (MHCS) are then reasonably designed as a sulfur host for high-capacity and long-life Li–S battery, in which MHCS can guarantee the high sulfur loading and fast electron/ion transfer. It is revealed that the shuttle effect is efficiently inhibited because of the boosted conversion of LiPSs. As a result, the coin cell based on the MHCS@MoS2-S cathode exhibits stable cycling performance maintaining 735.7 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at 1.0 C. More importantly, the pouch cell employing the MHCS@MoS2-S cathodes achieves high specific capacity of 1353.2 mAh g−1 and prominent cycle stability that remaining 960.0 mAh g−1 with extraordinary capacity retention of 79.8% at 0.1 C after 170 cycles. Therefore, this work paves a new avenue for developing practical high specific energy and long-life pouch-type Li–S batteries. Graphical abstract The MoS2 nanosheets decorated on mesoporous hollow carbon spheres (MHCS) are prepared as a dual-functional accelerator towards LiPSs conversion for high-capacity and long-life pouch-type Li–S batteries. Image, graphical abstract Key words Lithium sulfur batteries MoS2 Dual-functional accelerator Pouch cell 1 Introduction With the expansion of the market in high energy density storage systems such as electric vehicles (EVs), the requirements for high-energy-density batteries with long service life are ever-increasing [1]. Among the next-generation rechargeable batteries beyond lithium-ion batteries, lithium–sulfur (Li–S) system with high theoretical specific energy of 2550 Wh kg−1 are recognized as one of the most promising candidates to satisfy emerging market demands [2–4]. Besides, elemental sulfur has the conspicuous merits of low cost, natural abundance and environmental benignancy. Despite these advantages, the practical applications of Li–S batteries are prevented by several technical challenges, including the low electrical conductivity of both sulfur and lithium sulfide (Li2S), the large volume expansion of sulfur upon lithiation, and the undesirable “shuttle effect” of soluble lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) which dominate the fast capacity decay, low Coulombic efficiency and poor cycle stabilities of Li–S batteries. To tackle the above obstacles, numerous porous carbon materials were developed as sulfur hosts to confine LiPSs within pore structure [5–7]. However, the physical confinement of nonpolar carbon materials is limited because of the weak physical Van der Waals adsorption towards polar LiPSs [8]. In light of this, polar materials were utilized to mitigate the diffusion based on the strong chemisorption towards LiPSs [9–13]. Nevertheless, the liquid-solid conversion of soluble LiPSs to solid Li2S is essentially sluggish which gives rise to the inevitable diffusion of LiPSs and results in unsatisfactory cycling performance [14,15]. Consequently, accelerating the conversion kinetics of LiPSs to Li2S is recognized as a promising strategy to minimize the diffusion of LiPSs and realize long cycle life [16–19]. So far, many compounds with high catalytic activities have been reported to boost the electrochemical conversion kinetics of LiPSs and suppress the shuttle effect, such as metal oxides (Fe2O3 [20] , MnO2 [21], V2O3 [22]), metal sulfides (CoS2 [23], NiS [24], WS2 [25]), metal carbides (Ti3C2 [26], W2C [27], Mo2C [28]) and metal nitrides (TiN [29], Co4N [30], VN [31]). For example, Yang's group designed and synthesized a hierarchical porous graphene macrostructure incorporated homogeneous α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles by hydrothermal method as a novel sulfur host [20]. The α-Fe2O3 nanoparticles could not only support a polar surface for strong chemisorption with LiPSs, but also catalyze the soluble long-chain LiPSs to insoluble Li2S that were verified by the results of LiPSs adsorption and electrochemical measurements, respectively. Cheng's group developed a conductive porous vanadium nitride/graphene (VN/G) composite as an improved sulfur host [31]. The calculated binding energy between VN and LiPSs suggested the strong anchoring effect of VN towards LiPSs. Besides, the boosted LiPSs redox reactions confirmed by cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements indicated the catalytic activities of VN. Zhang et al. incorporated sulfiphilic CoS2 into carbon/sulfur cathodes to enhance the cycle performance of Li-S battery [23]. The strongly coupled CoS2-polysulfides interaction was investigated by theoretical approach. Moreover, the symmetrical Li2S6-Li2S6 cells were assembled to directly testify the catalytic activity of CoS2 on the redox reactions of LiPSs. Apart from boosting the redox kinetic of soluble LiPSs, the oxidation kinetic of Li2S is another critical characteristic to increase the active species utilization because of the low electrical conductivity and high charge transfer resistance of Li2S [32–35]. However, comparing to the numerous works reported on the sulfur reduction catalysis, as far as we know, the catalysis towards Li2S oxidation has not been widely studied. Therefore, considering the significant impacts of propelling LiPSs reduction and Li2S oxidation on the electrochemical performance, it is important to develop dual-functional catalyst for the sulfur cathodes of Li-S batteries. Since 2D MoS2 nanosheets were demonstrated as effective catalyst for accelerating LiPSs conversion [36], numerous attentions have been attracted [37–42]. Considering the limited electrical conductivity of MoS2, most researchers utilized graphene to facilitate electron transfer [41–45]. Nevertheless, the open channel structure in graphene based electrode is unfavorable for the restriction of soluble LiPSs. Besides, a clear consensus on the detailed catalytic mechanism of MoS2 towards the redox reaction of LiPSs has not been achieved due to the lack of systematic investigations. Moreover, comparing to the impressive performances based on coin cells, few pouch cells have been reported so far which cannot provide valuable guidance for the industrialization of Li–S batteries. In this work, we demonstrate for the first time that MoS2 can reduce the Gibbs free energy for rate-limiting step of sulfur reduction and the dissociation energy of Li2S by theoretical calculations. And the mesoporous hollow carbon spheres coated by MoS2 nanosheets (MHCS@MoS2) are rationally designed as a sulfur host which significantly accelerate both sulfur reduction and Li2S oxidation as expected, contributing to suppressed shuttle effect of LiPSs and prolonged lifespan for high-capacity Li–S batteries. Consequently, the coin cell based on the MHCS@MoS2-S cathode manifests long-term cyclic stability remaining 735.7 mAh g−1 with an ultralow capacity decay of 0.050% per cycle after 500 cycles at 1.0 C. Moreover, the pouch cell employing the MHCS@MoS2-S cathodes is also assembled and achieves high initial specific capacity of 1353.2 mAh g−1 and prominent capacity retention of 79.8% maintaining 960.0 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C after 170 cycles, indicative of the wide practicability of the MHCS@MoS2-S cathodes for high-capacity and long-life pouch-type Li–S batteries. 2 Experimental 2.1 Theoretical calculations The density functional theory (DFT) computations were performed using the CASTEP code which is integrated in Materials Studio 8.0 package. The interaction between the ionic core and valence electrons was described by the projector augmented wave method (PAW) [46]. The electron exchange correlation energy was calculated by the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) corrected the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) functional [47]. The DFT-D2 method of TS was used for dispersion corrections. The Kohn–Sham orbitals were expanded in a plane wave basis with a kinetic energy cutoff energy of 400 eV. The total energy convergence and the forces on each atom were set to be lower than 10−5 eV and 0.05 eV Å−1 for geometry optimization. A 5 × 5 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point mesh was employed to sample the Brillouin zone for the monolayers of MoS2 and carbon separated by 15 Å of vacuum [48]. The binding energy (E b) of the lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) on MoS2 monolayer or carbon monolayer substrate was calculated as following: (2.1) E b = E sub + E LiPSs − E sub + LiPSs where E sub is the energy of the clean substrate, E LiPSs is the energy of the isolated LiPSs cluster, and E sub+LiPSs is the energy of the substrate adsorbed with the LiPSs cluster. Besides, the barriers for Li2S dissociation on carbon or MoS2 substrates was calculated to evaluate the delithiation reaction kinetics. 2.2 Synthesis of MHCS@MoS2 composites Mesoporous hollow carbon spheres (MHCS) were prepared according to the previous literature [49]. 60 mg of the synthesized MHCS were dispersed in 60 mL deionized water by ultrasonic bath for 1 h. Then 90 mg Na2MoO4•2H2O and 0.9 g l-cysteine were added and dissolved under stirring for 10 min. The mixture was transferred into a 100 mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave to react at 220 °C for 24 h in an oven. After cooling to room temperature, the resultant black products were separated by centrifugation, washed with deionized water and ethanol for five times, and dried at 75 °C overnight. Finally, the MHCS@MoS2 powders were annealed at 700 °C for 3 h under 10% H2/Ar atmosphere in a tube furnace to improve the crystallinity of MoS2. 2.3 Preparation of MHCS-S, MHCS@MoS2-s composites The as-synthesized MHCS, MHCS@MoS2 composites and sublimed sulfur with weight ratio of 1:3 were mixed in agate mortar. The as-obtained mixture powders were sealed in glass bottle and heated at 155 °C for 12 h and 300 °C for another 2 h under argon atmosphere in a tube furnace. Then, the products were heated at 200 °C for 30 min under argon atmosphere with a flow rate of 50 mL min−1 to remove the outside redundant sulfur. 2.4 Polysulfides adsorption study The Li2S6 solution (0.5 mol L−1) was prepared by adding 25 mmol Li2S and 125 mmol sublimed sulfur in 50 mL 1, 3-dioxolane (DOL) and dimethoxymethane (DME) (v/v = 1/1) under continuous vigorous stirring for 24 h, according to previous reports [23]. Dilute Li2S6 test solution was prepared by adding 0.1 mL of above Li2S6 solution in 9 mL of DOl/DME (v/v = 1/1). Then MHCS and MHCS@MoS2 materials with the equal surface area were added into Li2S6 solutions as adsorbents, followed by vigorous stirring for 12 h. After then, the solutions were centrifuged. The supernatant was tested by UV–vis spectroscopy and the precipitates were dried in the vacuum transfer bin of the glove box for further XPS tests. All procedures were completed in an Ar-filled glove box in which O2 and H2O contents are below 0.1 ppm. 2.5 Characterization The composite crystal structures were determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) on X'pert Pro-diffractometer (50 kV, 50 mA) with a Cu Kα radiation. The content of sulfur and MoS2 were carried out by thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) with a Mettler TGA/DSC 3+ (Mwttler Toledo AG, Switzerland) in argon (for the measurement of the sulfur content) or in air (for the measurement of the MoS2 content). Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of the composites were measured at 77 K with a surface area analyzer (Autosorb iQ2). The morphologies of the composites were recorded by field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM) on a JSM-7800F, by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) on a JEM-2100 microscopy, and by elemental analysis on a JEOL 2100F system. UV/vis spectra was carried out with a Perkin Elmer Lambda 950 spectrometer. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on Escalab 250xi system. 2.6 Symmetrical cell assembly and measurements for catalytic analysis MHCS@MoS2 (MHCS, the controlled sample) and binder polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) in a weight ratio of 9:1 were homogeneous mixed in N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP) solvent under stirring to prepare slurry which was then coated on the carbon coated Al foil, followed by vacuum-dried at 100 °C overnight. The MHCS@MoS2 and MHCS electrodes were used as identical working and counter electrodes, while 30 μL electrolyte consisting of 0.5 mol L−1 Li2S6 and 1 mol L−1 lithium bis (trifluoromethane) sulfonamide (LiTFSI) dissolved in DOL/DME (v/v = 1/1) was added. Besides, the electrolyte without Li2S6 was served as blank control. CV and EIS were conducted on the PARSTAT 2000 electrochemical measurement system. The CV curves obtained with the assembled symmetrical cells were recorded in the range from −1.0 V to 1.0 V at different scan rates. 2.7 Li–S coin cell assembly and measurements The MHCS-S and MHCS@MoS2-S cathodes were prepared by casting NMP slurry containing active materials, Super P and PVDF in a weight ratio of 8:1:1 onto the carbon coated Al foil, followed by vacuum-dried at 55 °C overnight. The average sulfur loading is about 1.5 mg cm−2. The electrolyte contains 1 mol L−1 LiTFSI in DOL/DME (v/v = 1/1) with 0.2 mol L−1 LiNO3 as additive and the amount of electrolyte was controlled 20 μL mg−1 (S). The 2016-type coin cells with Celgard 2500 as separator and lithium metal as the counter electrode were assembled in an argon-filled glove. CV and EIS were measured on the PARSTAT 2000 electrochemical system. EIS measurements were carried out in the range of 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz at a perturbation amplitude of 5 mV. The galvanostatic charge–discharge profiles were performed between 1.7 V and 2.8 V at different rates (1 C = 1675 mAh g−1) using a CT2001A cell test instrument (LANHE). The charge–discharge capacities of the cells were all calculated based on the mass of sulfur in the cathodes. 2.8 Li–S pouch cell assembly and measurements The ball-milling method was applied to prepare NMP slurry consisted of MHCS@MoS2-S (MHCS-S for contrast), Super P and PVDF in a ratio of 8:1:1. Then the slurry was casted onto both sides of the carbon coated Al foil. The dried electrodes were cutted into 3 × 4 cm size followed by vacuum-dried at 55 °C overnight. Then 15 pieces of MHCS@MoS2-S cathodes with a sulfur loading of 1.5 mg cm−2 and 16 pieces of lithium foils with a thickness of 100 μm were cross stacked separated by Celgard 2500. The ratio of “cathode capacity/anode capacity” for the pouch-type cell is about 0.244. The Al-plastic film was used to seal the Li–S pouch cell after adding electrolyte. Finally, the galvanostatic charge-discharge tests of as synthesized Li–S pouch cell were measured between 1.7 V and 2.8 V at 0.1 C rate (1 C = 1675 mAh g−1) using a CT2001A cell test instrument. 3 Results and discussion To explore the catalytic mechanisms of MoS2 towards LiPSs, the DFT calculations are performed. It is well known that the adsorption of LiPSs on the surface of catalyst is the prerequisite for catalytic process. At first, all the possible binding geometries of the S-containing species with MoS2 or carbon are distinguished and shown schematically in Fig. 1 (a and b). And the binding energies corresponding to each pattern were also calculated. As can be seen, lithium atoms in LiPSs are adjacent to sulfur atoms in MoS2 to form stronger Li–S bond, driven by the electrostatic affinities of donor–acceptor pairs (sulfur and lithium in the case), which can be explained by Lewis acid-base interaction [50]. Besides, for each binding geometry MoS2 substrate delivers the much higher binding energies towards the LiPSs molecules than carbon indicating the stronger chemisorption between MoS2 and LiPSs. The free energies involved in each pathway of sulfur reduction and Li2S oxidation on the surface of MoS2 and carbon respectively were further calculated using theoretical calculations as previously reported [51]. The overall electrochemical reduction of sulfur is composed of several processes [52]: At first, S8 is reduced to Li2S8, and then to Li2S6 and Li2S4, accompanied by the reactions between the S-containing species in high valence state and those in low valence state. Then the insoluble Li2S2 and the final product Li2S will be generated. Fig. 1(c) presents the free energies diagrams for the sulfur reduction and the corresponding structures of the intermediates on the surface of MoS2 or carbon. It can be found that the Gibbs free energies for the reduction of S8 to Li2S8 both on the surface of MoS2 and carbon are most negative signifying the fast nature of kinetic. While the subsequent four steps to generate Li2S6, Li2S4, Li2S2 and Li2S are either endothermic or nearly thermoneutral, suggestive of the sluggish reaction kinetics. In particular, the reduction of Li2S2 to solid state Li2S has the largest Gibbs free energy in both cases of MoS2 and carbon, indicating that it is the rate-limiting step in the whole sulfur reduction. Notably, the Gibbs free energies for the conversion of Li2S2 to Li2S on the surface of carbon are 0.99 eV while only 0.77 eV on MoS2. Therefore, the lower Gibbs free energy for rate-limiting step of sulfur reduction endows MoS2 as a compelling highly efficient catalyst to accelerate the conversion of soluble LiPSs and restrain the shuttle effect in the discharge process. On the other hand, when Li2S is electrochemically oxidized on the surface of MoS2 or carbon, the Li–S bond will be broken at first to release one Li+ and LiS (Li2S LiS + Li+ + e) [51]. Hence, the dissociation energies and the energy barriers for the process occurred on the surface of both carbon and MoS2 were calculated by linear synchronous transit/quadratic synchronous transit (LST/QST) method to evaluate the oxidation kinetics. As displayed in Fig. 1(d), the calculated dissociation energy and barrier of Li2S on carbon are 2.12 eV and 2.14 eV, respectively, while substantially reduced to 0.77 eV and 0.96 eV on MoS2 substrate (Fig. 1e). It is validated that MoS2 is also the effective accelerator to reduce the dissociation energy of Li-S bonds as well as the energy barrier for Li2S oxidation. Consequently, the oxidation kinetic of electrochemical oxidation of Li2S was improved effectively. Therefore, we shed light on the mechanisms for the first time that MoS2 can act as a dual-functional accelerator towards both sulfur reduction and Li2S oxidation. MHCS were prepared as the substrate in view of the high electrical conductivity and specific surface area for MoS2 accelerator. The synthetic procedures of MHCS@MoS2-S composites are schematically illustrated in Fig. 2 (a). The prepared SiO2@C composites display uniform nanospheres with average diameter of ~300 nm as shown by TEM image (Fig. S1a). After SiO2 removal, the obtained MHCS not only remain the uniform spherical shape (Fig. 2b), but also generate mesoporous shell on the surface as displayed by high resolution scanning electron microscopy (HRSEM) image (Fig. S1b). What's more, TEM image demonstrates the hollow morphology of MHCS and a thickness of ~40 nm mesoporous shell with apparent open channels (Fig. S1c). As shown in Fig. 3 (a), Raman spectroscopy of MHCS reveals two peaks at ~1338 cm−1 and ~1587 cm−1 corresponding to D band and G band, characteristic of the defects in the graphite structure and the vibration of sp 2 hybridized carbon atoms in a 2D hexagonal lattice, respectively [53]. The value of I D /I G (1.52) manifests the relative low degree graphitization and high amorphous of MHCS. In addition, XRD pattern of MHCS delivers a broad peak at 21.7° and a weak peak at 43.4° relating to the (002) and (101) diffractions of the graphitic materials which also attest the amorphous structure of MHCS (Fig. 3b). As revealed by SEM and TEM images in Fig. S1(d) and Fig. 2(c), the coated MoS2 show the nanosheets structure. High resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) image of MHCS@MoS2 (Fig. 2d) exhibits that the lattice spacing of MoS2 nanosheets is 0.68 nm which is in accordance with the (002) planes of MoS2 phase. Besides, selected area electron diffraction (SAED) also displays the characteristic diffraction rings of MoS2 (inset Fig. 2d) and demonstrates the polycrystallinity of MoS2. The Raman spectroscope of MHCS@MoS2 (Fig. 3a) delivers the characteristic peaks of MoS2 at 380 (E1 2g) and 402 cm−1 (A1g) corresponding to the in-plane and out-of-plane Mo-S phonon modes, respectively [39]. Moreover, XRD pattern of the MHCS@MoS2 composites confirms that pure phase MoS2 is obtained (JCPDS No. 37-1492, lower panel of Fig. 3b). In addition, the EDX elemental mapping of the resultant MHCS@MoS2 materials were depicted in Fig. 2(e). The element molybdenum and sulfur are dispersed homogeneously indicating the uniform coating of MoS2 nanosheets. The weight ratio of MoS2 in MHCS@MoS2 composites was determined by TGA as shown in Fig. 3(c). The MHCS and MHCS@MoS2 materials were further conducted by nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms measurements. The MHCS@MoS2 composites have a high surface area of ~ 742.0 m2 g−1 and a pore volume of 1.026 cm3 g−1 benefiting from the high surface area of MHCS substrate (1431 m2 g−1). In addition, the MHCS@MoS2 composites deliver a similar pore size distribution of 5–15 nm as that of MHCS, mainly derived from the SiO2 template (Fig. S2), contributing to the subsequent sulfur immersing and fast transfer of Li ion. The MHCS@MoS2 and MHCS materials with the similar surface area as adsorbents were added into the Li2S6 solution with the same amount to conduct adsorption experiments. The Li2S6 solution was prepared and diluted in DOL and DME solvent leading to a yellow color solution [27]. As illustrated in Fig. 4 (a), the Li2S6 solution with the addition of MHCS still presented a similar yellow color compared to the blank LiPSs solution indicating the weak physisorption between the nonpolar MHCS and the polar LiPSs. However, the color of Li2S6 solution faded after the addition of MHCS@MoS2 materials in 12 h, validating the strong chemisorption of MHCS@MoS2 towards Li2S6. Moreover, the content of residual element sulfur in the solution was tested by UV/vis spectroscopy as shown in Fig. 4(b). Obviously, the characteristic adsorption peak at around 420 nm which is attributed to Li2S6 in the DOL/DME solution [54] completely vanished after adding MHCS@MoS2 composites. This experiment undoubtedly verifies the strong chemisorption between MoS2 and Li2S6 which is consistence with the theoretical calculation results. For additional insights into the detailed chemisorption mechanism between MoS2 and Li2S6, the samples retrieved from the adsorption test were further measured by XPS. The Li 1s spectrum of pristine Li2S6 exhibits a characteristic peak at around 56.1 eV (Fig. 4c), while shifts to 55.3 eV after addition of MHCS@MoS2 composites suggesting the increase of electron cloud of Li atom (Fig. 4d) [55]. In addition, Fig. 4(e) shows the high-resolution Mo 3d & S 2s spectra of the pristine MHCS@MoS2 materials. Three peaks located at 232.6 eV, 229.5 eV and 226.7 eV were corresponding to Mo 3d 3/2, Mo 3d 5/2 and S 2s of divalent sulfide ions (S2−), respectively. For comparison, the intensity of Mo 3d peaks of the MCHS@MoS2–Li2S6 obviously declined with the appearance of new satellite peaks located at 232.1 eV and 228.8 eV indicating the increase of Mo atom electron cloud (Fig. 4f) [32]. These phenomena suggest the formation of Li–S bond, accompanied by the charge transfer from the electronegative S atom of MoS2 to the electropositive Li atom of Li2S6 which subsequently induces the increase of electron cloud of Mo atom. This speculation is well consistent with the theoretical calculation result. Consequently, based on the above experiments, it can be concluded that MoS2 possess strong chemical interaction towards LiPSs with the formation of Li-S bond, which can greatly immobilize and adsorb the soluble LiPSs species. To assess the catalytic performance of MoS2, the symmetrical cells with two identical MHCS@MoS2 electrodes in 0.5 mol L−1 Li2S6 electrolyte were assembled and tested. From the voltammograms of the MHCS@MoS2 symmetrical cell at a scan rate of 1 mV s−1 (Fig. 5 a), four reversible redox current peaks at −0.40 V, −0.05 V, 0.40 V and 0.05 V can be clearly observed. On the contrary, symmetrical cells without the addition of Li2S6 were also measured which delivered negligible current. Therefore, it can be speculated that the redox peaks are mainly ascribed to the redox reactions of active species Li2S6. There is only one peak denoted as C2 located at −0.40 V appeared in the first cathodic scan from the open circuit voltage to −1.0 V. Accordingly, it can be inferred that peak C2 is derived from the reduction of Li2S6 to Li2S on the working electrode and oxidization of Li2S6 to S8 on the counter electrode since Li2S6 is the only electrochemically active species in the electrolyte. And peak A1 and A2 in the following anodic scan are originated from the oxidation of Li2S to Li2S6 and then S8 on the working electrode, respectively. Peak C1 is attributed to the reduction of S8 to Li2S6 which then participate in the reduction in the following cycle. The specific redox equations of four peaks are displayed in Fig. S3. In contrast, the redox peaks of Li2S6 on the MHCS electrodes are dwarf and the peak potentials are hysteretic, indicating the sluggish redox reaction kinetics of LiPSs (Fig. S4 and Fig. 5b). Moreover, the similar differences can be observed when increasing the scan rate as displayed in Fig. S5(a and b), demonstrative of the accelerated redox kinetics of LiPSs on MHCS@MoS2 electrodes. It can be concluded that the redox reactions of LiPSs are dramatically accelerated by MoS2 nanosheets as well revealed by theoretical calculations. Elemental sulfur was then introduced into MHCS@MoS2 composites and MHCS for controlled by traditional melt-diffusion method. The XRD pattern of the MHCS@MoS2-S hybrid materials confirms the presence of sulfur (Fig. 3b). The sulfur content in MHCS@MoS2-S and MHCS-S is determined to be 72.1 wt% and 74.5 wt%, respectively, measured by TGA (Fig. S6). The elemental mapping images suggests that sulfur was successfully immersed into the hollow cavity and mesoporous carbon shell (Fig. S7). Thus, the obtained core-shell MHCS@MoS2-S composites encapsulated the active sulfur species as expected. To evaluate the electrochemical performances of the obtained MHCS@MoS2-S materials in Li-S battery, the 2016-type coin cells were fabricated using MHCS@MoS2-S as the cathodes and metal lithium as the anodes. CVs curves of Li-S cells with MHCS@MoS2-S electrodes in the potential range of 1.7–2.8 V (vs Li/Li+) at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1 for the first five cycles are shown in Fig. 5(c). The MHCS@MoS2-S cathode displays two characteristic cathodic peaks at 2.32 V (vs. Li+/Li, denoted I) and 2.01 V (denoted II) in the second cycle which are corresponded to the reduction of sulfur (S8) to high order long-chain Li2S x (4 ≤ x ≤ 8) and further to Li2S, respectively [56]. Two closed anodic peaks at 2.35 V (denoted III) and 2.42 V (denoted IV) represented the oxidation of Li2S to the formation of LiPSs and sulfur. As comparison, the cathodic peaks of MHCS-S electrode in the second cycle are located at approximately 2.26 V and 1.96 V whose potentials are more negative as shown in Fig. S8. In addition, the cathodic peak at 1.96 V is broadened and dwarf comparing to the sharp peak of MHCS@MoS2-S at 2.01 V (Fig. 5d). Consequently, the narrower cathodic peak and more positive reduction potential testify that the reduction of sulfur to final product Li2S is accelerated by MoS2 nanosheets. On the other hand, MHCS@MoS2-S cathode shows a sharper anodic peak with a more negative oxidation potential that manifest the accelerated oxidation of Li2S to sulfur comparing to MHCS-S. In the next four cycles, the similar differences in shape and potential between MHCS@MoS2-S and MHCS-S cathode are still remained. Therefore, the kinetics of sulfur reduction and Li2S oxidation in the sulfur cathode are significantly propelled by MoS2 nanosheets which is consistent with the theoretical calculations. EIS was also employed to evaluate the redox kinetics of MHCS@MoS2-S and MHCS-S cathodes. The Nyquist plots were fitted with the equivalent circuit as the inset of Fig. 5(e) shown and the fitting results are summarized in Table S1. The high frequency intercept at the real X-axis represents the ohmic resistance (R e) of the cell. The semicurve at high frequency is corresponding to the interfacial resistance (R SEI) and the semicurve at medium frequency is ascribed to charge transfer resistance (R ct). The straight line (Warburg impedance) in the low frequency region is assigned to semi-infinite diffusion [57]. The ohmic resistance of MHCS@MoS2-S and MHCS-S cathodes are similar before/after cycling. Noticeably, the charge transfer resistance of MHCS@MoS2-S before/after cycling are 58.04 Ω/26.45 Ω, which are much smaller than the values obtained with MHCS-S (83.89 Ω/43.27 Ω), indicating the accelerated redox kinetics (Table S1). What's more, the linear fitting plot of Z′ versus ω −1/2 are shown in Fig. 5(f). And the square of the slope of the plot is inversely proportional to the solid-state diffusion coefficient of Li-ions. And the MHCS@MoS2-S exhibit higher Li-ion diffusion coefficient before/after cycling than those of MHCS-S (Table S1). It's reasonable to speculate that the reduction kinetic of the solid-state reaction of Li2S2 to Li2S is enhanced by MHCS@MoS2-S cathode which is consistent with the calculated lower Gibbs free energy for this rate-limiting step. Visible Li–S cells with different cathodes were assembled to directly observe the generation and diffusion of the LiPSs during the discharge process, as Fig. S9 illustrated. For the cell containing MHCS-S cathode, there is obvious color change after 1 h discharging at 0.1 C rate, especially nearby the cathode, demonstrating that LiPSs easily dissolve into the electrolyte and diffuse from MHCS-S electrode. However, the electrolyte is rendered completely colorless even after 9 h of discharge when using the MHCS@MoS2-S electrode. Thus, it is manifested that the core-shell MHCS@MoS2-S cathode successfully restrains the diffusion of LiPSs in ether based electrolyte attributing to the boosted conversion of soluble LiPSs to solid Li2S by MoS2 catalyst. The cyclic performance of the MHCS@MoS2-S cathode was further investigated. Fig. 6 (a) shows the consecutive cycling performance of the MHCS@MoS2-S and MHCS-S cathodes at different C-rates measured for ten cycles at each current in the scope of 0.1 to 2.0 C, following by the recovery at 0.1 C. Obviously, the MHCS@MoS2-S cathode delivers a higher discharge capacity at first ten cycles at 0.1 C while the MHCS-S cathode declines rapidly, although the similar initial discharge capacities are obtained. With increasing the discharging current density, the specific capacity of MHCS@MoS2-S is gradually reduced to 1110.8, 1014.9, 950.1 and 886.0 mAh g−1 at 0.2, 0.5, 1.0 and 2.0 C, respectively. When the C-rate return back to 0.1 C, the reversible capacity of the MHCS@MoS2-S cathode is recovered to 1074.0 mAh g−1. In contrast, the specific capacity of MHCS-S electrode drops quickly to 973.4, 847.7, 732.6 and 650.7 mAh g−1 correspondingly and only 662.6 mAh g−1 reversible capacity can be achieved when the C-rate returned back to 0.1 C. Consequently, it is quite clear that higher specific capacities can be obtained for all applied current densities in the case of using MHCS@MoS2-S cathode comparing to MHCS-S cathode. Moreover, the charge-discharge profiles of the MHCS@MoS2-S and MHCS-S cathodes at different current rates from 0.1 to 2 C are presented in Fig. 6(b). The MHCS@MoS2-S cathode exhibits the voltage difference (ΔE 1) of 150 mV between the charge plateau and the second discharge plateau in the first cycle at 0.2 C, which is smaller than that of 180 mV (ΔE 2) for MHCS-S cathode (Fig. S10). What's more, as shown in Fig. 6(b), when increasing the charge-discharge current density, the difference between ΔE 1 and ΔE 2 is larger and larger. In other words, the MHCS@MoS2-S cathode presents much better rate capability than the MHCS-S cathode, although the electrical conductivity of MoS2 is poor than carbon. This is mainly attributed to the accelerated kinetics for the redox reactions of LiPSs by the MoS2. In this case, the polarization of both sulfur reduction and Li2S oxidation can be effectively reduced by MoS2. Next, the cyclic stability of the MHCS@MoS2-S was further performed at 0.1 C as shown in Fig. 6(c). A high reversible capacity of 887.7 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles is remained. In contrast, the discharge capacity of MHCS-S cathode fades gradually to 554.9 mAh g−1. Besides, it is verified that the capacity contribution of MHCS@MoS2 host is negligible (Fig. S11). In addition, the long cyclic performance was also examined at 1.0 C as shown in Fig. 6(d). The MHCS@MoS2-S cathode achieves a reversible discharge capacity of 735.7 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles corresponding to a capacity retention of ~78.0% calculated by using the value of the 2nd cycle. Simultaneously, a capacity decay as low as 0.050% per cycle is obtained with high Coulombic efficiency of nearly 100%, indicative of the restrained shuttle effect of LiPSs. In a sharp contrast, the discharge capacity of MHCS-S cathode declines to 305.2 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles with only 29.6% retention and a high capacity decay of 0.243% per cycle. In a word, MHCS@MoS2-S cathode exhibits the superiority in high discharge capacity, excellent rate capability and cyclic stability that validate the important role of dual-functional accelerator MoS2 in sulfur cathode. Moreover, for the purpose of evaluating the practicability of MoS2 accelerator, the pouch cell by employing the MHCS@MoS2-S cathodes were fabricated and detected. As shown in Fig. 6(e), the LED light was powered by the as-prepared pouch cell. An initial capacity of 732 mAh is achieved corresponding to a specific capacity of 1353.2 mAh g−1 (based on the mass of sulfur) at 0.1 C rate (Fig. 6f). And the specific energy of the pouch cell is calculated to be 1260 Wh kg−1 based on the mass of the active materials. What's more, the pouch cell remains a specific capacity of 960.0 mAh g−1 even after 170 cycles corresponding to a capacity retention as high as 79.8% from the 2nd cycle. As a contrast, the pouch cell employing the MHCS-S cathodes only remain 838.3 mAh g−1 after 50 cycles along with the decreasing Coulombic efficiency (Fig. S12). To the best of our knowledge, there are rarely reports [58–60] on the Li–S pouch cell with long cyclic stability exceeding 170 cycles up to date. For the lifespan of the pouch-type cell, the capacity decline is possibly due to the decay of both the MHCS@MoS2–S cathode and the lithium anode. The detailed investigations will be conducted in the future. Table 1 displays the cycling performance of recently reported MoS2 based sulfur host in Li–S batteries. It can be found that this dual-functional MHCS@MoS2-S cathode exhibits salient superiority, especially in pouch cell, which undoubtedly confirms its possibility of practical applications for high-capacity and long-life Li–S batteries. The compelling high-capacity and long-life Li–S batteries were mainly attributed to the rational design of core–shell MHCS@MoS2 sulfur host, as illustrated in Fig. 6(g). First, MHCS guarantee the high sulfur loading, fast electron/ion transfer and contribute to the homogeneous distribution of MoS2 nanosheets. Second, the coated MoS2 nanosheets with abundant polar sites can efficiently capture the dissolved long-chain LiPSs driven by the strong chemisorption derived from the formation of Li–S bond. Third, MoS2 can significantly accelerate the conversion of the adsorbed LiPSs to solid state Li2S due to the reduced Gibbs free energy of sulfur reduction. Besides, MoS2 can also catalyze the oxidation of Li2S back to LiPSs because of the decreased dissociation energy of Li2S. Therefore, the rationally designed MHCS@MoS2-S cathodes effectively suppress the shuttle effect of LiPSs and increase the utilization of Li2S, which thereby enhance the specific capacity and lifespan for practical pouch-type Li-S batteries. 4 Conclusions In summary, we shed light on the catalytic mechanism of MoS2 by theoretical calculations for the first time that the Gibbs free energy for rate-limiting step of sulfur reduction and the dissociation energy of lithium sulfide (Li2S) are both reduced. Thereby the core-shell MHCS@MoS2 were rationally designed and synthesized, in which MHCS ensured the high sulfur loading, constructed fast electron/ion transfer, and MoS2 served as a dual-functional accelerator towards both the sulfur reduction and Li2S oxidation benefiting to inhibited shuttle effect and prolonged lifespan for high-capacity Li–S batteries. The prepared MHCS@MoS2-S coin cell exhibited an excellent cycling stability which remained 735.7 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at 1.0 C with a low capacity decay rate of 0.050% per cycle. In particular, the assembled MHCS@MoS2-S pouch cell simultaneously achieved high specific capacity of 1353.2 mAh g−1 (S) at 0.1 C and extraordinary capacity retention of 79.8% after 170 cycles, indicating it a promising cathode candidate for high specific energy Li-S batteries. Therefore, this proposed strategy will provide a new insight to develop highly efficient sulfur cathodes for practical high-capacity and long-life Li-S pouch cells. coredata.dc:description: Developing sulfur cathodes with high catalytic activity on accelerating the sluggish redox kinetics of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) and unveiling their mechanisms are pivotal for advanced lithium–sulfur (Li–S) batteries. Herein, MoS2 is verified to reduce the Gibbs free energy for rate-limiting step of sulfur reduction and the dissociation energy of lithium sulfide (Li2S) for the first time employing theoretical calculations. The MoS2 nanosheets coated on mesoporous hollow carbon spheres (MHCS) are then reasonably designed as a sulfur host for high-capacity and long-life Li–S battery, in which MHCS can guarantee the high sulfur loading and fast electron/ion transfer. It is revealed that the shuttle effect is efficiently inhibited because of the boosted conversion of LiPSs. As a result, the coin cell based on the MHCS@MoS2-S cathode exhibits stable cycling performance maintaining 735.7 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at 1.0 C. More importantly, the pouch cell employing the MHCS@MoS2-S cathodes achieves high specific capacity of 1353.2 mAh g−1 and prominent cycle stability that remaining 960.0 mAh g−1 with extraordinary capacity retention of 79.8% at 0.1 C after 170 cycles. Therefore, this work paves a new avenue for developing practical high specific energy and long-life pouch-type Li–S batteries.

coredata.dc:title: Rational design of MoS2 nanosheets decorated on mesoporous hollow carbon spheres as a dual-functional accelerator in sulfur cathode for advanced pouch-type Li–S batteries
